title: Module 3 Assignment
text:
An exercise in descriptive statistics!
This was a lot of fun!

# LIS4273 - Module 3. Assignment
# Robert Walsh
# Professor Lingyao Li
#
library(DescTools)
# Import the two data sets from .csv file
dataSets<-read.csv("C:/LIS4273blog/Mod3DataSets.csv",header = TRUE,sep = ",")
dataSets

  Set.1 Set.2
1    10    20
2     2    12
3     3    13
4     2    12
5     4    14
6     2    12
7     5    15

# (A1) For each set, compute the mean, median, 
# and mode under Central Tendency
#
# ----------------
# CENTRAL TENDENCY
# ----------------
# Set # 1, Mean:
mean(dataSets$Set.1)

[1] 4

# Set # 1, Median:
median(dataSets$Set.1)

[1] 3

# Set # 1, Mode:
Mode(dataSets$Set.1)

[1] 2
attr(,"freq")
[1] 3

# ----------------
# CENTRAL TENDENCY
# ----------------
# Set # 2 Mean:
mean(dataSets$Set.2)

[1] 14

# Set # 2 Median:
median(dataSets$Set.2)

[1] 13

# Set # 2 Mode:
Mode(dataSets$Set.2)

[1] 12
attr(,"freq")
[1] 3

# (A2) For each set, compute the range, interquartile, 
# variance, and standard deviation under Variation
#
# ---------
# VARIATION
# ---------
set1_minMax<-range(dataSets$Set.1)
# The Min & Max of Set # 1 are:
set1_minMax

[1]  2 10

set1_range<-set1_minMax[2]-set1_minMax[1]
# The Range of Set # 1 is:
set1_range

[1] 8

quartileSet1<-quantile(dataSets$Set.1)
# The Quartiles of Set # 1 are:
quartileSet1

  0%  25%  50%  75% 100% 
 2.0  2.0  3.0  4.5 10.0 

interQuartileRangeSet1<-as.numeric(quartileSet1[4])-as.numeric(quartileSet1[2])
# The InterQuartile Range for Set # 1 is:
interQuartileRangeSet1

[1] 2.5

# The Variance of Set # 1 is:
var(dataSets$Set.1)

[1] 8.333333

# The Standard Deviation of Set # 1 is:
sd(dataSets$Set.1)

[1] 2.886751

# ---------
# VARIATION
# ---------
set2_minMax<-range(dataSets$Set.2)
# The Min & Max of Set # 2 are:
set2_minMax

[1] 12 20

set2_range<-set2_minMax[2]-set2_minMax[1]
# The Range of Set # 2 is:
set1_range

[1] 8

quartileSet2<-quantile(dataSets$Set.2)
# The Quartiles of Set # 2 are:
quartileSet2

  0%  25%  50%  75% 100% 
12.0 12.0 13.0 14.5 20.0 

interQuartileRangeSet2<-as.numeric(quartileSet2[4])-as.numeric(quartileSet2[2])
# The InterQuartile Range for Set # 2 is:
interQuartileRangeSet2

[1] 2.5

# The Variance of Set # 2 is:
var(dataSets$Set.2)

[1] 8.333333

# The Standard Deviation of Set # 2 is:
sd(dataSets$Set.2)

[1] 2.886751

# (A3) Compare your results between Set # 1 vs. Set # 2
# by discussing the differences between the two sets.
#
# --------------------
# SUMMARY / COMPARISON
# --------------------
#
cv1<-(sd(dataSets$Set.1)/mean(dataSets$Set.1))*100
cv2<-(sd(dataSets$Set.2)/mean(dataSets$Set.2))*100
compdf<-data.frame("Mean"=c(mean(dataSets$Set.1),mean(dataSets$Set.2)),
"Median"=c(median(dataSets$Set.1),median(dataSets$Set.2)),
"Mode"=c(Mode(dataSets$Set.1),Mode(dataSets$Set.2)),
"Range"=c(set1_range,set2_range),
"Variance"=c(var(dataSets$Set.1),var(dataSets$Set.2)),
"Std Dev"=c(sd(dataSets$Set.1),sd(dataSets$Set.2)),
"CV"=c(cv1,cv2),
row.names = c("Set.1","Set.2"))
compdf

      Mean Median Mode Range Variance  Std.Dev       CV
Set.1    4      3    2     8 8.333333 2.886751 72.16878
Set.2   14     13   12     8 8.333333 2.886751 20.61965

summary(dataSets$Set.1)

   Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max. 
    2.0     2.0     3.0     4.0     4.5    10.0 

summary(dataSets$Set.2)

   Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max. 
   12.0    12.0    13.0    14.0    14.5    20.0 

# ------------------------
# COEFFICIENT OF VARIATION
# ------------------------
# Coefficient of variation, as percent:
# Set # 1:
cv1

[1] 72.16878

# Set # 2:
cv2

[1] 20.61965

# Although both sets had an equal range and variance...
# They had significantly different means.
# The set of data that has the greatest spread of variance
# relative to the mean is:
if (cv1>cv2) {paste("Set # 1, Coefficient of Variance = ", cv1, "VS.", cv2)
} else {paste("Set # 2, Coefficient of Variance = ", cv2, "VS.", cv1)}

[1] "Set # 1, Coefficient of Variance =  72.1687836487032 VS. 20.6196524710581"

title: Module 2 Assignment
text:
This Function Calculates The Mean!
Here is how it works!

# LIS4273 - Module 2. Assignment
# Robert Walsh
# Professor Lingyao Li

# Create a vector using the c() function
# and store the results in the 'assignment2' variable/object

assignment2 <- c(6,18,14,22,27,17,22,20,22)

# Create a function named 'myMean' that will
# accept 'assignment2' as an input variable/argument and then
# calculate & return the value of the sum of all values in the
# 'assignment2' vector using the sum() function, and then divide
# that result by the number of components in the 'assignment2'
# vector using the length() function. the result is stored in the
# 'result' variable/object.

myMean <- function(assignment2) 
{
  return(sum(assignment2)/length(assignment2))
}

# print the result as output by calling 'myMean' with 
# 'assignment2' as the argument

result <- myMean(assignment2)
result

[1] 18.66667

# Here is the output!

title: Module 4 Assignment
text:
An exercise in probability!

# LIS4273 - Module 4. Assignment
# Robert Walsh
# Professor Lingyao Li
#
table1<-data.frame("B"=c(10,20,30),"B1"=c(20,40,60),"Totals"=c(30,60,90),
row.names = c("A","A1","Totals"))
library(gridExtra)
grid.table(table1)







#Question A.
#Based on Table 1, what is the probability of:
#A1. Event A ?
A<-30/90
paste("The probability of event A = ",format(round(A,4)),"%")

[1] "The probability of event A =  0.3333 %"

#A2. Event B ?
B<-30/90
paste("The probability of event B = ",format(round(B,4)),"%")

[1] "The probability of event B =  0.3333 %"

#A3. Event A or B ?
AorB<-((30/90)+(30/90))-(10/90)
paste("The probability of event A or B = ",format(round(AorB,4)),"%")

[1] "The probability of event A or B =  0.5556 %"

#A4. P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B)
AorB == A + B

[1] FALSE

# Question B.
# In terms of probabilities, we know the following:
# P( A1 ) = 5/365 =0.0136985 [It rains 5 days out of the year.]
# P( A2 ) = 360/365 = 0.9863014 [It does not rain 360 days out of the year.]
# P( B | A1 ) = 0.9 [When it rains, the weatherman predicts rain 90% of the time.]
# P( B | A2 ) = 0.1 [When it does not rain, the weatherman predicts rain 10% of the time.]
# We want to know P( A1 | B ), the probability it will rain on the day of Jane's wedding,
# given a forecast for rain by the weatherman. 

# The answer can be determined from Bayes' theorem, as shown below.

# P( A1 | B ) = P( A1 ) P( B | A1 ) / P( A1 ) P( B | A1 ) + P( A2 ) P( B | A2 )
# P( A1 | B ) = (0.014)(0.9) / [ (0.014)(0.9) + (0.986)(0.1) ]
# P( A1 | B ) = 0.111
# Note the somewhat unintuitive result. Even when the weatherman predicts rain,
# it only rains only about 11% of the time. 
# Despite the weatherman's gloomy prediction, there is a good chance that Jane
# will not get rained on at her wedding.

# Please answer the following questions:
# B1. Is this answer True or False ?
print("TRUE")

[1] "TRUE"

# B2. Please explain why:
cat("Bayes' Theorem takes into account your initial belief about the event
(like the usual chance of rain for the day) before new information is considered. 
Even though the weatherman correctly predicts rain 90% of the time..
The base probability of rain is already low, 5/365 = 1.36%.
Even if the weatherman predicts rain,
the new information isn't strong enough to significantly update the probability
high enough to consider it a \"high chance\" of rain.
The \"likelihood ratio\" is not large enough
to drastically change the initial low probability of rain.")

Bayes' Theorem takes into account your initial belief about the event
(like the usual chance of rain for the day) before new information is considered. 
Even though the weatherman correctly predicts rain 90% of the time..
The base probability of rain is already low, 5/365 = 1.36%.
Even if the weatherman predicts rain,
the new information isn't strong enough to significantly update the probability
high enough to consider it a "high chance" of rain.
The "likelihood ratio" is not large enough
to drastically change the initial low probability of rain.

# Question C.
# Last assignment from our textbook, pp. 55 Exercise # 2.3.
# For a disease known to have a postoperative complication frequency of 20%,
# a surgeon suggests a new procedure. She/he tests it on 10 patients and found
# there are not complications.

# C1.You will answer this question with the following code.
# What is the probability of operating on 10 patients successfully
# with the traditional method?
paste("The probability is:",dbinom(x=0,size=10,prob=.20),"%")

[1] "The probability is: 0.1073741824 %"
